questions.text:
Arrange the following in the correct order from proximal to distal:

1. Alveolar duct

2. Lobar bronchi

3. Terminal bronchiole

4. Alveolar sac

5. Segmental bronchi

6. Respiratory bronchiole
questions.solution:
The following is a sequence of the intrapulmonary anatomy from proximal to distal: Trachea → Main Bronchi → Lobar Bronchi → Segmental Bronchi → Terminal Bronchiole → Respiratory Bronchiole → Alveolar Duct → Alveolar Sac → Alveoli

According to Weibel’s model, the respiratory tract is divided into 23 generations, consisting of conducting (upper 16 generations) and respiratory zones (lower 7 generations). It begins at the trachea (designated as zero) and ends with alveoli (last generation).

The epithelial layer transitions from a pseudostratified columnar layer in the upper airways (trachea, bronchi) with submucosal secretory glands to a cuboidal epithelium (bronchioles), and finally, to a flat squamous epithelium in the alveoli, facilitating efficient gas exchange in the respiratory zone. 

As we progress downward, the following changes occur in the structure of the airways: 

  • The number of mucus-secreting cells/secretory glands decreases.
  • The amount of cartilage in the airway wall decreases.  
  • The quantity of smooth muscles increases from trachea to terminal bronchioles but decreases from respiratory bronchioles to alveoli.
  • The amount of dead space decreases.
  • The number of cilia decreases such that they are absent in alveoli.
  • The surface area and volume progressively increase, facilitating easy gas exchange.
  • The number of flat squamous cells (Type 1 pneumocytes) increases.

The diagram given below further reiterates the above concept

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady, with a past history of pulmonary tuberculosis, presents to the OPD with complaints of infertility. After further evaluation, you diagnose her with genital tuberculosis. The most common structure involved in this condition is derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
The most common structure involved in genital tuberculosis are the fallopian tubes which develop from the Mullerian ducts (paramesonephric ducts).

Three parts can be recognized in each paramesonephric duct: (1) a cranial vertical portion that opens into the abdominal cavity, (2) a horizontal part that crosses the mesonephric duct, and (3) a caudal vertical part that fuses with its partner from the opposite side.

With the descent of the ovary, the first two parts develop into the fallopian tube, and the caudal parts fuse to form the uterine canal.

The upper vaginal wall, uterus and cervix also develop from the Mullerian ducts.

Derivatives of the urogenital sinus:

  • Lower vagina
  • Skene’s tubercles
  • Bartholin’s gland
  • Urinary bladder 
  • Urethra

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not related to the posterior surface of the vagina?
questions.solution:
Waldeyer's fascia (presacral fascia) forms the posterior relationship of the rectum and is not related to the vagina. It lines the anterior surface of the sacrum.

Relations of the vagina:

Parts of vagina Anterior relation Posterior relation Lateral relation
Upper third Bladder Peritoneum of the rectouterine pouch

Levator ani

Transverse cervical ligament

Pubocervical ligament

Uterosacral ligament

Ureter and uterine artery (related to the lateral fornix)
Middle third Bladder Rectovaginal fascia/septum Pubovaginalis muscle
Lower third Urethra Perineal body Bulbospongiosus

questions.text: A 24-year-old medical student received booster dose of Hepatitis B vaccination, following which she developed weakness in the abduction and lateral rotation of that arm. The lesion is most likely to be in which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The axillary nerve also called a Surgeon's nerve is frequently injured during inadvertent intramuscular (IM) injections. 

Named nerves of the upper limb:

  • Laborer’s nerve: Median nerve.
  • Musician’s nerve: Ulnar nerve.
  • Surgeon’s nerve: Axillary nerve.
  • Nerve of Bell: Long thoracic nerve.

Course of Axillary nerve:

  • Origin -  Posterior cord of brachial plexus in the axilla. 
  • In Axilla - Exits the axilla through the quadrangular space to enter the arm.
  • In Arm - Winds around the surgical neck of the humerus and gives cutaneous supply to the lower part of deltoid "upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm".

Axillary nerve Injury: 

Injury mostly is due to fracture of surgical neck of humerus, inferior dislocation of humerus and inadvertent IM injection.

Test: Loss of sensation over the skin of the lower part of the deltoid muscle (regimental badge anesthesia) in case of lesion of the nerve.

questions.text: The given area of the anterior surface of the left kidney is related to the ________________ :
questions.solution:
The given area on the anterior surface of the left kidney is related to the jejunum.

 The anterior relations of the right kidney include:

  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Second/descending part of the duodenum
  • Liver
  • Hepatic flexure of the colon
  • Small intestine

The anterior relations of the left kidney include:

  • Left suprarenal gland 
  • Stomach
  • Pancreas
  • Jejunum
  • Spleen
  • Splenic flexure and the beginning of the descending colon

The posterior relations of the kidneys are as follows:

  • Vessels (1): Subcostal vessels
  • Ligaments (2): Medial and Lateral Arcuate ligaments
  • Nerves (3): Subcostal, Iliohypogastric, and Ilioinguinal nerves
  • Muscles (4): Diaphragm, Psoas major, Quadratus lumborum, and Transverses abdominis.
  • The right kidney is related to the 12th rib and the left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl playing with small magnets suddenly develops breathlessness. Chest X-ray shows an inhaled foreign body in one of the bronchi. Where does the vein supplying the most likely site of obstruction drain into?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario of an inhaled foreign body, it is most likely to lodge into the right bronchus. The right bronchial veins drain to the azygos vein. 

Left bronchial veins drain into the accessory hemiazygos vein or left superior intercostal vein.

Clinical significance:

The right principal bronchus is wider, shorter, and more vertical. This is why an inhaled foreign body is more likely to lodge there. Also, the tracheal bifurcation directs the foreign body to the right lung

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to the structure marked in the given image of the liver?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the falciform ligament of the liver. It is an embryological derivative of ventral mesentery, which itself arises from septum transversum. 

Septum transversum is the undifferentiated lateral plate mesoderm at the cranial end of the embryo. It gives rise to:

  • Central tendon of diaphragm
  • Fibrous pericardium
  • Liver stroma
  • Ventral mesogastrium

As the liver grows into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum, ventral mesentery is divided into two parts:

  1. Lesser omentum, which extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver (hepato-gastric and hepato-duodenal ligaments)
  2. Ligaments of the liver: all ligaments of the liver except ligamentum teres are derived from the ventral mesentery. This includes falciform ligament, right and left triangular ligaments, and coronary ligaments. 

Dorsal mesentery connects the abdominal organs to the posterior abdominal wall. It runs from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut. Depending on the abdominal organ to which it is attached, it has multiple regions: dorsal mesogastrium, mesoduodenum, mesentery proper (to the small intestine), mesocolon, mesoappendix, mesosigmoid, and mesorectum. The dorsal mesogastrium gives rise to greater omentum, gastrosplenic ligament, lienorenal ligament, and gastrophrenic ligament.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with rigidity, frequent falls, slow movements, tremors, and a short stepping gait when he entered the doctor's room. Which of the following areas is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease, which is associated with the degeneration of substantia nigra (marked as "C").

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Postural instability along with bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are cardinal features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Notable gait abnormalities are:

  • Short stepped gait- parkinsonism
  • Scissoring gait- spasticity i.e. UMN lesion
  • High-stepped, slapping gait- posterior column or peripheral nerve disease
  • Waddling gait- proximal muscle weakness
  • Wide stepping gait - cerebellar dysfunction

questions.text: A patient presented with tenderness in the region shown below following a fall on an outstretched hand. Which of the following forms the roof of this region?
questions.solution:
The marked region is the anatomical snuffbox. The superficial branch of radial nerve forms the roof of the anatomical snuffbox. Tenderness in this region is suggestive of a scaphoid fracture, a common injury after a fall on an outstretched hand.

Anatomical snuffbox boundaries: 

Lateral wall:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL),
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)  

Medial wall:

  • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL).

Roof:

  • Cephalic vein
  • Superficial branch of radial nerve

Floor:

  • Radial styloid, Scaphoid, Trapezium, and 1st Metacarpal. 

Only content: Radial artery

The name "snuffbox" originates from the use of this surface for placing and then sniffing powdered tobacco, or snuff.

questions.text: After removing the parotid gland, the patient presents with sweating on the cheeks while eating. This reflects aberrant innervation of which nerve?
questions.solution:
The above symptoms reflect aberrant innervation of the auriculotemporal nerve.

The patient experiencing sweating on cheeks while eating, is the symptom of Frey's syndrome or gustatory sweating or auriculotemporal syndrome.

  • It commonly develops after parotid surgery or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule.
  • During the regrowth, an aberrant connection develops between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the sweat glands. This results in sweating, warmth and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.
  • Management - The symptoms can be treated by subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area and use of antiperspirant. Denervation by tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve may be useful.

questions.text: Identify the structures which consist of commissural fibres:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is A, B, and C only.

The structure marked as 'D' is the body of the fornix and it mainly contains association fibres. The commissure of the fornix (hippocampal commissure) contains the commissural fibers. 

A- Corpus callosum

B- Anterior commissure

C- Posterior commissure

D- Body of the Fornix

The locations of the commissural fibers are:

  • Corpus callosum- Medial surface of the brain
  • Anterior commissure- Beneath the rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Posterior commissure- In the inferior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Habenular commissure- In the superior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Hippocampal commissure- Between the right fornix and the left fornix 

(Note: Varied information regarding the fibers present in the Fornix. 41st edition Gray's Clinical anatomy mentions Fornix under association fibers, the commissure of the fornix under commissural fibers. Whereas, Snell's Neuroanatomy textbook mentions the Fornix under commissural fibers.)

questions.text: While evaluating a cyanotic newborn, his echocardiogram shows pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. Which developmental structure's defective maturation is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
This newborn is found to have pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. The structure that gives rise to the root of the pulmonary artery is the truncus arteriosus, marked as '4' in the given image.

Structures marked:

  1. Sinus venosus
  2. Atrium
  3. Bulbus cordis
  4. Truncus arteriosus

The heart tube begins to bend by day 23. This bending creates the cardiac loop which is completed by day 28. The fate of various structures formed as a result of this bending is as follows:

Given below are the heart tube and their derivatives:

 Part of the heart tube Derivative structure in the heart

Bulbus cordis

  • Proximal 1/3 

 

  • Middle 1/3 (conus cordis)

 

  • Distal 1/3 (truncus arteriosus)

 

  • Trabeculated part of right ventricle

 

  • Outflow tract of right and left ventricles

 

  • Root and proximal portions of aorta and pulmonary artery
Primitive ventricle
  • Trabeculated part of the left ventricle
Primitive atrium
  • The common atrium that splits to right and left atrium

questions.text: The type of joint involved in the following movement of the neck is?
questions.solution:
The joint for side-to-side movements in the neck is the atlanto-axial joint which is a type of pivot joint.

Movement in the atlanto-axial joints are simultaneous and consists almost exclusively of rotation around the axis, which helps a person look to the right and left. 

  • The normal range of atlanto-axial rotation is about 40°.
  • The orientation and shape of the atlanto-occipital joints allow mainly for flexion–extension, which has a total range of about 15°.

Pivot joint:

In pivot joint, one bone rotates in relation to another bone.

This is a uniaxial joint, and thus rotation is the only motion allowed at a pivot joint.

Eg:

  • Atlantoaxial joint: the first cervical (C1) vertebra (atlas) rotates around the dens, the upward projection from the second cervical (C2) vertebra (axis). This allows the head to rotate from side to side as when shaking the head “no.”
  • The proximal radioulnar joint is a pivot joint formed by the head of the radius and its articulation with the ulna. This joint allows for the radius to rotate along its length during pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

questions.text: A fresh high school graduate attended an Army recruitment drive but was rejected due to his flat foot. The primary ligament in his foot that is most likely responsible for this condition is the _______.
questions.solution:
A flat foot is caused due to the involvement of the spring ligament.

Pes planus or flat foot is caused to due the collapse of the medial longitudinal arch of the foot and can be either congenital or acquired. Its causes include rupture of spring ligament, tarsal coalition, disruption of tibialis posterior tendon, tarsometatarsal arthritis, and hindfoot degenerative or inflammatory arthritis.

Spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali to the navicular. It ties the calcaneus to the navicular and maintains the medial longitudinal arch of the foot. It is made up of the superomedial calcaneonavicular portion and the inferior calcaneonavicular portion.

It supports the head of the talus which if fails or is destroyed, leads to separation of the navicular and calcaneus, in turn allowing the talar head, the highest point of the arch, to descend and leading to a flat-foot deformity.

Other options:

Option B: The anterior talofibular ligament is the “ankle sprain ligament” because it is the one that is most often damaged when the ankle is rolled.

Option C: The posterior talofibular ligament functions to stabilize the ankle joint and subtalar joint. Injuries are rare to this ligament unless there is an ankle dislocation or subluxation.

Option D: The deltoid ligament is extremely strong and stabilizes the inside of the ankle. Tears of this ligament are most common when the ankle undergoes an unstable ankle fracture.

Related Pearl: Comparative features of the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot.

Features

Medial Longitudinal arch

Lateral longitudinal arch

Anterior pillar

Talus, navicular, 3 cuneiform and 1st, 2nd and 3rd metatarsal

Cuboid and 4th, 5th metatarsals

Posterior pillar

Medial half of calcaneum

Lateral half of calcaneum

Main joint involved

Talo calcaneonavicular joint (TCN)

Calcaneocuboid joint

Summit

Superior articular surface of Talus

Superior articular surface of calcaneum at the leveled Subtalar joint

Extremities (piers)

Tuberosity of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 1st, 2nd, 3rd metatarsal anteriorly

Plantar surface of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 4th, 5th metatarsals anteriorly

Ligament/intersegmental ties

Plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament)

Long and short plantar ligaments

Tie beams

Plantar aponeurosis (medial part)

Abductor hallucis

Medial part of  flexor digitorum brevis

Plantar aponeurosis (lateral part)

Abductor digiti minimi

Slings

Tibialis posterior

Flexor hallucis longus

Flexor digitorum longus

Sling formed by tibialis anterior and peroneus longus

Peroneus longus

Peroneus brevis

questions.text: An elderly man with atherosclerosis presented with abdominal pain and blood-stained stools.  CECT abdomen is suggestive of ischemic colitis at the splenic flexure involving the marginal artery of Drummond. What are the arteries contributing to the formation of this structure?

choices.text: Right colic and left colic arteries
Left colic and middle colic arteries

questions.solution:
The middle and left colic arteries contribute to the formation of the marginal artery of Drummond at the splenic flexure. The splenic flexure (Griffith's point) is a watershed area of the colon which is more prone to ischemia. 

The anastomotic vessel that runs in the mesentery along the inner margin of the colon is called the marginal artery of Drummond. From this artery, numerous small branches are given to the large bowel. It is formed by:

  • Branches of superior mesenteric artery - middle colic, right colic, and ileocolic arteries
  • Branches of inferior mesenteric artery - left colic, sigmoid, and superior rectal arteries

When ischemia occurs at Griffith's point, the blood supply in this region is augmented by another arterial loop called the inner arterial arc (of Riolan). This arc connects the main trunk of the middle colic artery with the ascending branch of the left colic artery.

Note: Sudeck's point is another watershed area present at the rectosigmoid junction. The sigmoid artery anastomoses with the superior rectal artery at this site.

questions.text: Fracture of the jugular canal can present as

choices.text: Loss of taste sensation in anterioir 2/3rd of tongue
Loss of taste sensation in posterior 1/3rd of tongue
Loss of general sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue
Loss of motor sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue

questions.solution:
Fracture of the jugular canal affects glossopharyngeal nerve and presents as loss of taste sensation in the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. 

The lingual nerve which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve gives general sensation, chorda tympani branch of facial nerve gives taste sensation for the anterior 2/3rd of tongue. Both taste and general sensation of the posterior 1/3rd is by the glossopharyngeal nerve. The muscles of the tongue, with the exception of palatoglossus, are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. Palatoglossus is supplied via the pharyngeal plexus.

The other nerves passing through the jugular foramen are glossopharyngeal(cranial nerve IX), vagus(cranial nerve X), and accessory nerve(cranial nerve XI).

The following is an image of the base of skull showing jugular foramen:

questions.text: A patient has dry eye and reduced nasal secretions. The location of a lesion might be in the ____.
questions.solution:
In this patient with dry eye and reduced nasal secretions, the lacrimal gland, and glands of the nasal mucosa are affected. So the lesion is possibly in the sphenopalatine ganglion.

Parasympathetic (secretomotor) supply to the lacrimal gland, glands of the nasal mucosa and palate travel in the nerve of the pterygoid canal i.e, Vidian nerve, and reach the sphenopalatine ganglion (a.k.a Pterygopalatine ganglion or nasal ganglion) where they relay before reaching the target. They also supply the blood vessels of the nose and cause vasodilation.

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.
  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.
  LACRIMAL GLANDS SUBMANDIBULAR GLAND
SUBLINGUAL GLAND		 PAROTID GLANDS

Lacrimatory nucleus

Pons

Superior salivatory nucleus

Pons

Inferior salivatory nucleus

questions.text: A patient with traumatic injury to the skull is diagnosed to have an epidural hematoma. The area of impact is at the pterion, causing damage to the underlying artery. Which of the following foramen does this artery traverse through?
questions.solution:
Traumatic injury to the pterion can damage the underlying anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal artery enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum, labeled as 3 in the image.

The structures passing through the foramen spinosum are:

  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus 
  • Middle meningeal vein

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction that overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery leading to extradural hematoma. 

The four bones forming the pterion are:

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone


The foramina marked in the image are:

1 - Foramen rotundum
2 - Foramen ovale
3 - Foramen spinosum
4 - Jugular foramen

questions.text: An elderly man is diagnosed with a slow-growing tumor in the deep perineal pouch. Which of the following is not a content of this structure?
questions.solution:
The root of the penis, which consists of two crus and one bulb, is the content of the superficial perineal pouch.

The deep perineal pouch is used to describe the space enclosed between the endopelvic fascia and the perineal membrane and includes the following contents:

Males Common to both Females
  • Dorsal nerve of the penis
  • Artery of the penis
  • Origin  of the branches of the penile artery
  • Bulbourethral glands
  • Urethra
  • Deep transverse perinei
  • Sphincter urethrae
  • Origin of the urethral artery
  • Dorsal nerve of the clitoris
  • Artery of clitoris
  • Origin  of the branches of the artery of the clitoris

questions.text: An intern was asked to give an intravenous injection to a vein in the cubital fossa. All of the following are true about the cubital fossa except:

choices.text: Musculocutaneous nerve is one of the contents
Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally
Median cubital vein forms the roof

questions.solution:
The musculocutaneous nerve is not a content of the cubital fossa.

The cubital fossa is a triangular depression present in the anterior side of the elbow joint. The boundaries of the cubital fossa include:

  • Medially: Lateral border of the pronator teres
  • Laterally: Medial border of the brachioradialis (option A)
  • Base: Proximally by an imaginary line joining the epicondyles of the humerus
  • Apex (pointed downward): Joining of the lateral and medial boundaries.
  • Roof: Skin, superficial fascia containing median cubital vein (option D) joining the cephalic and basilic veins, lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, medial cutaneous nerve of the forearm, bicipital aponeurosis, and deep fascia.
  • Floor: Brachialis and supinator muscles.

The contents of the brachial fossa are (from medial to lateral side):

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery, terminating into radial and ulnar arteries
  • Biceps brachii tendon with the bicipital aponeurosis
  • Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally (option C) in the groove between the brachialis and brachioradialis

Clinical significance:

  • The median cubital vein is the most commonly preferred vein of choice for intravenous injections. 
  • Auscultation of the brachial artery in front of the elbow helps in measuring the blood pressure.

questions.text: The muscle marked by the arrow in the image below is innervated by ________
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the above image is levator scapulae, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve.

The appendicular group of back muscles and their innervations include:

Muscle  Nerve Supply

Trapezius

 Accessory nerve

Latissimus dorsi

 Thoracodorsal nerve

Levator scapulae

 Dorsal scapular nerve

Rhomboid major and minor

 Dorsal scapular nerve

Other options:

Option B: The suprascapular nerve innervates the supra- and infraspinatus muscles.

Option D: The subscapular nerves supply the teres major and subscapularis muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following Couinaud segments of the liver drains directly into the inferior vena cava?
questions.solution:
Segment 1 (Caudate lobe) drains directly into the Inferior vena cava(IVC).

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage.

The left lobe is composed of the left lateral segment (Couinaud’s segments II and III) and the left medial segment (segment IV). The right lobe is composed of segments V, VI, VII, and VIII, with segments V and VIII making up the right anterior lobe and segments VI and VII making up the right posterior lobe.

Segment I corresponds to the caudate lobe of the liver and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver. Segment IV is divided into segments IVa and IVb.

All the Couinaud segments are supplied by the portal vein and hepatic artery for the arterial supply. Venous drainage of Couinaud segments II to VIII drained into right and left hepatic veins except for segment I (Caudate lobe) which drains directly into the Inferior vena cava. All segments drained lymph into respective right and left hepatic ducts.

questions.text: Which part of this bone is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa?
questions.solution:
The part of the scapula marked as 1 is the coracoid process and it is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa. The tip of the coracoid process lies approximately 2.5 cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral to the infraclavicular fossa (deltopectoral triangle). Hence, the coracoid process can be palpated below the clavicle.

The coracoid process arises from the upper border of the neck of the scapula and it projects forwards and slightly laterally. Attachments at the coracoid process include 

  • The conoid portion of the coracoclavicular ligament 
  • Pectoralis minor 
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament 
  • Glenocorocoid ligament 
  • Coracobrachialis muscle

Other options 

Option B - Acromian process continues from the spine of the scapula. The acromion is subcutaneous over its dorsal surface, The attachments at the acromion are the coracoacromial ligament, the articular capsule of the acromioclavicular joint, and horizontal fibers of the trapezius. 

Option C - The glenoid fossa is present at the lateral angle of the scapula. It is articular with the humerus to form the shoulder joint. 

Option D - The inferior angle lies over the seventh rib. Dorsally, it is related to latissimus dorsi. The angle is visible when the arm is raised over the head.

Parts of the scapula are given in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hybrid muscle?
questions.solution:
The sternohyoid muscle marked as '3' is not a hybrid muscle. It is innervated only by the anterior rami of spinal nerves C1-C3 (via the ansa cervicalis)

Hybrid muscles are the muscles that are supplied by two different nerves with different root values.

Other muscles in the given image are:

1 - Trapezius

2 - Sternocleidomastoid

4 - Digastric muscle (anterior belly)

Hybrid muscles of head and neck: 

  • Digastric - Anterior belly is supplied by the nerve to the mylohyoid and posterior belly is supplied by the facial nerve.
  • Trapezius and sternocleidomastoid (SCM) - Motor supply is by the spinal accessory nerve and the proprioception is by ventral rami of cervical nerves (C2, C3 for SCM and C3, C4 for trapezius).

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant was brought to the pediatric OP for a routine checkup. The child had congenital hypoparathyroidism. CT scan revealed thyroid hypoplasia and absent thymus. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal pouches will most likely cause the given features?
questions.solution:
The defect is most likely to be present in the development of third and fourth pharyngeal pouches as the inferior parathyroid gland and thymus develop from 3rd pouch while the superior parathyroid gland and parafollicular cells of the thyroid develop from 4th pouch.

Derivatives of the Pharyngeal Pouches
1
  • Tympanic cavity (middle ear cavity)
  • Auditory tube (eustachian tube) 
2
  • Palatine tonsils
  • Tonsillar fossa
3
  • Inferior parathyroid glands (parathyroid III)
  • Thymus
4
  • Superior parathyroid glands (Parathyroid IV)
  • Ultimobranchial body - gives rise to parafollicular (C) cells of the thyroid gland

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in a patient with sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve. Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following varicose vein surgery.

The saphenous nerve is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body. It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. It then enters the adductor canal and exits it by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over the patella. The saphenous nerve then descends along the medial border of the tibia along with the great saphenous vein (anterior to the vein) and supplies the skin on the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

During stripping of veins in varicose surgery, injury to the saphenous nerve is common as it closely travels with the great saphenous vein. Sensory loss over the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot is observed in saphenous nerve injury. 

Other options: 

Option A: Sural nerve injury causes sensory loss over the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third of the leg and lateral side of the foot and fifth toe. It is often used as an autologous peripheral nerve graft as it is readily identified and easy to harvest.

Option B: Superficial peroneal nerve injury causes sensory loss over the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. It also causes weakness of foot eversion.

Option C: Deep peroneal nerve injury causes weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and toe extension but normal eversion of the foot.

questions.text: Area marked "?" in the diagram below is ________.
questions.solution:
The image is of the floor of the 4th ventricle, and the area marked "?" is the hypoglossal triangle.

The floor of the 4th ventricle is diamond-shaped and lies on the dorsal surface of the pons and superior half of medulla.

It is divided into two symmetrical halves by the longitudinal median sulcus. Each half is further divided by sulcus limitans into a medial region, medial eminence, and a lateral region, vestibular area.

The vestibular nuclei lie beneath the vestibular area.

At the superior end of the sulcus limitans, a bluish-gray area is produced by a cluster of nerve cells containing melanin pigment called substantia ferruginea.

At the inferior end of the medial eminence, the fibers from the motor nucleus of the facial nerve looping over the abducens nucleus are represented by the facial colliculus.

Inferiorly, the medial eminence is represented by the hypoglossal triangle overlying the hypoglossal nucleus and the vagal triangle overlying the dorsal nucleus of vagus.

questions.text: A man sustained a blow on the lateral aspect of fibula which is likely to result in all of the following features except ________

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the dorsum of foot
Loss of extension of great toe
Loss of sensation over lateral border of foot

questions.solution:
The patient is likely to have fracture involving the neck of the fibula, which is closely related to the common peroneal nerve.

Loss of sensation over the lateral border of foot is not seen in the injury to common peroneal nerve because this area is innervated by sural nerve which is a branch of tibial nerve.

Common peroneal nerve:

The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of fibula deep to peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of foot and to the skin over dorsal area of foot except the first webspace and lateral side of little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles and skin between great and second toes.

Causes of common peroneal nerve injury:

  • Fracture of the fibular neck: due to direct injury or indirect twisting injury of the lower limb
  • Pressure from a splint or a plaster cast over the neck of fibula
  • Postpartum nerve injury include injury to the peroneal nerve and injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve.

Injury to common peroneal nerve will lead to:

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop. So the patient attempts to lift the leg high enough during walking so that the foot does not drag on the floor. This is known as high stepping gait.
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss along the anterior and lateral side of the leg, dorsum of foot including the medial side of great toe.

 

Note: Ankle reflex is preserved in common peroneal nerve palsy.

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured
Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve
Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture humerus  Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve
Medial condyle of humerus  Ulnar nerve
Posterior dislocation elbow Ulnar nerve >Median nerve
Monteggia fracture Posterior interosseous nerve
Volkman’s ischemic contracture Anterior interosseous nerve
Hook of hamate fracture Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Lunate dislocation  Median nerve
Wrist injury Median nerve
Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve
Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)

questions.text: The marked area in the given image is supplied by which dermatome?
questions.solution:
The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: 

  • The skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus is supplied by T7-T9.
  • The skin around the umbilicus is supplied by T10.
  • The skin below the umbilicus until the suprapubic region is supplied by T11, T12. 
  • The skin around genitalia and upper medial thigh is supplied by L1.

questions.text: Circle of Willis does not get a contribution from
questions.solution:
Circle of Willis does not get a contribution from the middle cerebral artery.

The circle of Willis is located in the interpeduncular fossa at the base of the brain. It is an anastomosis between the internal carotid arteries and vertebral arteries. It allows the blood entering from either artery to be distributed to both the cerebral hemispheres.

The arteries forming the circle of Willis are:

  • Anterior communicating artery
  • Anterior cerebral arteries
  • Internal carotid arteries
  • Posterior communicating arteries
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Basilar artery

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis
